name: What makes a strong low-level (1-10) build?
author: Mick Dagger

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
What would be your favourite build if you played somewhere where there was a very low max level limit? What is your strongest level 1 character, your best level 2 character, level 3 character etc?

All normal character development takes us through the early Levels, and you normally play more low level characters than high level characters since you don't take all characters to mid- or high levels. Many mods also end before level 10.

At low levels life can be really hard. Your character has few hitpoints, low AB, bad equipment, and can suffer one hit kills. Power comes at intervals and different classes have different points at which they gain that extra power. Eg; Warrior classes get an extra attack at level 6, casters get new spell levels at every second Level. Fighters gain a lot of feats early on. Rangers get a pet at Level 6 etc.

So what is your level 1 powerbuild, level 2 powerbuild etc?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I am in a hurry so i will try a stab at this, but to me it seems an ITWF warrior is at great advantage here as far as offense goes.
Of course a Strength-based Cleric will do very well too.
Full tumble, isn't as crucial to a character in that level range.

And to give an actual example of where such a character is useful, there is of course the Hall of Fame series of modules " Saleron's Gambit " where your character begins at 1st lvl and goes up to 10th -11th lvl at the end.
There are also other modules that require low-level characters. Two of which i have good memories of, are "Conan Chronicles-Legion of the Dead" and "Lord of the Rings-Sons of the Steward".
Both are relatively short in comparison to "Saleron's Gambit" but well-made adventures with fantastic music themes.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just an instinct, but I'd have thought 9 levels of Ranger - as a dual-wielding dexer - should be pretty decent, and 1 level of either Barbarian (speed, rage and a few more HPs), Monk (tumble and maybe more AC if WIS features quite strongly) or Cleric (again, if there's a WIS synergy). Human makes sense for the extra skills and feat, but something in me thinks a Hin might be a good bet.

As ever, I speak merely as an amateur!

posts.content:
1. Doesn't the strength of a build depend on the environment? I mean if you have a solo environment where you absolutely have to pick locks, all these builds would be FUBARed, right? OK, I know that's OTT, but my point is that some builds presume the presence of certain levels of equipment or consumables, or the challenge facing them, for example; others are more flexible.
2. When you say what's a strong level 1-10 build, are you building to a level you select, whether 1, 6 or 10 (say), or are you considering the situation at every level en route? I mean what happens if you play a module that you're not sure what level you'll end at - no use designing a build where the payoff happens a level past where you finish. Maybe that's a different challenge though...

Hi Thorsson - good to meet you.

1. To a certain extent, yes, you're right, environment will always play a part. However, part of this Guild's underpinning premise is to create builds that remain strong regardless of environment (bar some minor tinkering). Any potential game-changing environment-specific issues can be addressed when a build is first requested/conceived, as has been done in the past. For example, and on a simplistic level, anyone wanting to use a build solely to play the OC won't be focused on Dwarven waraxe. Equally, and more particular to your example, if pick locks is a necessary skill at such early levels as this thread is concerned with, shouldn't the module's author be letting players know that prior to beginning - else they will just be nerfing their own endeavours? The presumption here is vanilla, and that includes levels and types of equipment/consumables available unless told otherwise.

2. That was a question that concerned me on the first page of this thread, and I think the answer is no, these builds are about being among the strongest at their stated level, not the previous or any later one(s). And that's why they're on the General Discussion sub-forum rather than anywhere else.

Hope you enjoy your time with us!

This lvl 6 build has a "duality" in it. Not exactly yin/yang, comedy/tragedy mask or Dr Jekyll/Mr Hyde, but nevertheless...
You can choose between going dual wield and stealth in light armor, or sword and board in heavy armor. Shortsword fits both purposes, and gets the weapon focus because of the AB penalty while dual wielding. You are free to pick another weapon for sword'n board, without the +1 to AB, if you want a bigger weapon.
That's the reasoning behind my choice here.

Edit: Another option is to take WF in a medium sized weapon, and use it for sword'n board and in the main hand while dual wielding. But then you have to pick a small/tiny weapon without a WF for your off hand attack while dual wielding. Sword'n board gets better, and every second dual wield attack gets worse AB.
The total damage may improve slightly though, if you use both combat styles, so maybe you have spurred an improvement here Stag! 😎

You can choose between going dual wield and stealth in light armor, or sword and board in heavy armor. Shortsword fits both purposes, and gets the weapon focus because of the AB penalty while dual wielding. You are free to pick another weapon for sword'n board, without the +1 to AB, if you want a bigger weapon.
That's the reasoning behind my choice here.
